reviewText: A good addon to the Company of Heroes franchise. Adds two new playable teams; the British (a hardcore defensive team), and the Panzer Elite (very hit and run with good heavy tanks in endgame). Maps are also added but few in number. reviewText:
If you liked CoH, you'll like this. Opposing Fronts is a standalone expansion for Company of Heroes. It adds 2 new armies (The British and the Panzer Elite) for multiplayer/AI matches, two new campaigns for both factions, unique new doctrines and tons of new units with loads of abilities.
-Armies/Units
The British are a good solid defensive faction. Most of their power comes from emplacements you build.
Pros- Command Trucks are used for HQs, meaning you can place them in any of your secured territories, boosting its resource output. Heavy defensive positions like Slit Trenches, MG Positions, AT gun emplacements and Mortar emplacements can be built for a small amount of resources and population. Infantry can be upgraded with many different weapons, increasing their efficency against other infantry, light vehicles or heavy tanks. Their doctrines offer Commando Support which allows you to land a glider with 6 Commandos, a glider with a light tank that is effective against halftracks, infantry and other light tanks, and a HQ glider which allows the production of AT commandos, Mortar Commandos and HMG commandos.
Cons- They are purely defensive (unless you use the Commando Doctrine) and do not have much offensive capabilty. Their infantry walks very slowly through enemy or uncaptured territory to gain more defensive against attacks (which is annoying at the start). Their tanks (aside from the Sherman Firefly) all have small guns but heavy armor that can't do ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• against many medium to heavy tanks.
-The Panzer Elite are a very mobile faction. Most of their amor is made up of halftracks (which can be pretty powerful) but they can get some good heavy tanks and tank destroyers.
Pros- Great faction for quick and powerful attacks. Infantry halftracks let the garrisoned squad shoot out the top with any weapons they have (bazzokas, mgs or snipers). The Marder tank destroyer is extremely good with an ability to lock-down" making it immoblie but a faster rate of fire that does more damage. Almost all of their infantry can repair stuff.
Cons- As said before
date: their armor are halftracks.\n-Overall Score: 8.5/10\nA good game but better as an expansion to CoH 1."
helpfulPercent: 33 of 36 people (92%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Originally posted on November 24, 2007

Company of Heroes: Opposing Fronts is an expansion pack, but it is sold as a stand alone game, much like the recent Supreme Commander expansion. It provides two new campaigns, covering the Liberation of Caen as the British, and Operation Market Garden as the Panzer Elite. the inclusion of the Panzer Elite is an interesting touch, as few games to date have German campaigns. The campaigns have solid stories, and good replay values through different difficulty levels and medals. However, the game is not really about the campaigns; It is about the new factions, the Brits and the PE. They drastically change the balance of multiplayer, and needless to say, there are still some significant balance issues to work out.
All in all though, the new factions are great.

British-The British are all about defense. They have the capability to build some amazing defensive emplacements very early on, so watch out for that. Their infantry is very solid, but their armor is weak and expensive.

The Panzer Elite- The PE, contrary to their name, are not about panzers, but rather are about fast attacks with mechanized and motorized units. They have a wide variety of halftracks and armored cars, including mortar halftracks and AT halftracks. Perhaps their greatest weapon is their tank destroyer, the Marder II, which is one of the best in the game.

On an overall level, Opposing Fronts delivers, but if you are new to the franchise, try the original first.

reviewText:
NOTE 1:My game time should be around 500 hours by now if I count my time outside of Steam when I first bought this game in 2006.

NOTE 2:Also see my Company of Heroes Review here:
http://steamcommunity.com/id/miyumiayase/recommended/4560

Also see my Company of Heroes: Tales of Valor here:
http://steamcommunity.com/id/miyumiayase/recommended/20540

TL:DR? See Conclusion
INTRODUCTION:Company of Heroes: Opposing Fronts is a real-time strategy game developed by Relic Entertainment and published by THQ (RIP). This game serves as the first official expansion pack to the series which adds two new factions, new units, a German (Panzer Elite) and British campaigns along with new multiplayer maps.

The expansion pack 'Opposing Fronts' added 2 new campaigns for the new factions of Great Britain who's plot revolves around the British Royal Army's operation to retake and secure the city of Caen in northern France. On the other-hand, the new Axis campaign featured the Panzer Elite faction in their mission to foil an Allied Operation called 'Market Garden'.

PROS:+ Improved special effects
+ New Factions
+ German and British Campaigns
+ New Units are fun to play with
+ Standalone Expansion but...(See CON #3)
+ Allows players with the expansion to play with players without the expansions and vice versa

CONS:- Balance issues
- AI is somehow worse than the original
- Does not include the original armies unless you have the original game
- Campaign has some dull moments
- Inconsistent sound / voice levels for some of the units

CONCLUSION:GOOD EXPANSION but could have used a little more polish. Opposing Fronts is a great expansion that adds a lot of replayability to the original game by adding new factions; new units; new Campaign and a ton of improvements that increases the authentic feel and immersion of the game.

MUST BUY for RTS and World War 2 fans whether at full price or on sale. Although, I highly advice the 'Complete Pack' (which includes the original game and the 2 expansions) to have the full experience.

---------------------------------------------------------
Like my Reviews? Follow my Curator's Page:
http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861651-Miyumi%27s-Review-Corner/

reviewText: By far the best RTS. Relic have nailed the idea of making the whole genre more actiony. They did it with Warhammer but that stuck more to a particular audience and the slight cartoonish graphics put many off. Now in company of heroes it has polished graphics and a subject to suit a wider audience. WW2 although seems quite an over used subject for gaming, has never been as explored as this in an RTS form. The reason for giving it an 8 is because the new expansion was a marketing scheme all along. If you want to survive in multiplayer you must get this game otherwise your whermacht will be screwed by British artillery that can fire at your base from the other end of the map. Be sure to buy and play!

reviewText:
Company of Heroes: Opposing Fronts is a great standalone add-on for the main game.
It provides 2 new armies, 2 new campagins and few extra units for the main game (if you own it, that is).

You can use this Add-on as a seperate game and just use this content or you own the base game and the content adds up - you suddenly have 4 armies, a lot of campaigns and extra units.

Company of Heroes: Opposing Fronts does the same as the main game - great campaign, enjoyable sessions against AI players and one of the best and most balanced Multiplayer RTS games on the market.

10/10 the first of 2 great Add-on's to the main game.

reviewText:
One of the best real time strategy games ever made on the PC.  It has a complete destructable environment and unit cover system and suppression system.  Flanking the enemy really means something in this game.  I have played countless hours playing this series I definitely got my monies worth with the first game and the two stand alone expansions paying full retail price.

Getting this series for $9.99 on steam sale is a steal!  Also having this series on steam means it will auto patch to the proper version.   This series have been patched and balanced mutiple times and having to patch manualy is a pain.  Having this on steam is a very big bonus.

The Company of Heroes and Opposing Fronts has a long single player campain.  Also Opposing Fronts adds the British and German Panzer Elite forces.
Tales of Valor only has a very short campain.  But, focus heavily on mutiplayer with a few additional units for each force and different mutiplayer modes like  1vs1, 2vs2, 3vs3, 4vs4. and more!
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Opposing Fronts is a standard expansion. A very standard expansion. It does everything that an expansion is supposed to do, faction, units, maps, campaign. Adding new things within the same frame as the main game. The problem however is that none of it is particularly inspired.

Two new factions are introduced, a defensive British army and a mobile German one. However neither of them really brings anything new to the formula.

The campaigns are an utterly standard experience and although the cut-scenes and storyline have been heavily improved upon the gameplay is inferior to that of the original American campaign.

Opposing Fronts does what is needed, it gives the single-player fanatics a reason to take Company of Heroes back off the shelf. But it does not give them any reason to keep it down. It is a game that you play and then forget about a few days later.

reviewText: Company of Heroes: Opposing Fronts (CoH: OF) is an expansion of the ground-breaking real-time strategy (RTS) game, Company of Heroes. The game, of course, continues to use the same mechanics as the original with an added weather effect and offers two new campaigns for the British and German Panzer Elite (Kampfgruppe Lehr). CoH: OF is worthwhile and it should be a no-brainer for CoH fans, but whether or not you own CoH: OF - you still have interplayability with other players from the original.

reviewText:
The next chapter in the #1 rated RTS franchise thrusts players into a hellish war torn landscape to command two battle-hardened armies in relentless campaigns for honor and country. Players lead the tenacious British 2nd Army during the heroic World War II liberation of Caen, France, and command the German Panzer Elite as they struggle to repel the largest airborne invasion in history.

- Two New Armies: Play as the British 2nd Army or German Panzer Elite, each with devastating command trees options and unit upgrades.

- Two Full Campaigns: Command the British 2nd Army to liberate the key strategic position of Caen, France. Control the German Panzer Elite to repel the Allied airborne invasion in Operation Market Garden.

- Real War, Real Battlefields, Real War Enhanced: Mission Persistence, Dynamic Weather Effects, Enhanced Vehicle Tactics and more deliver a new level of realism and all new battlefield tactics.

- All new Multiplayer Options: Combine Company of Heroes‚Ñ¢: Opposing Fronts‚Ñ¢ with the original Company of Heroes for a total of four playable armies online. Join British artillery with American armor to dominate the 3rd Reich or utilize Wehrmacht and Panzer Elite blitzkrieg tactics to annihilate the Allied invasion.

If you're into an RTS game that's very based on World War 2, then this is the game for you!
Company of Heroes offers a wide, dynamic range of components you can use all to your discretion, or depending upon your play style. You can play the Americans, British, Wehrmacht, or the Panzer Elites.

You can go from building trenches with the British to enhance your soldiers survivability from artillery to surprising your opponents with Airborne from the Americans.

You can be the Wehrmacht and terrorize your opponents in any way possible with the mighty King Tiger (Tiger II respectively) or Blitzkrieg your way through enemies as if mowing the lawn". You can also be the Panzer Elites which specializes in infilitraton
recommended: and scorched earth tactics which is planting booby traps on Strategic Points and buildings to give your opponents the surprise of their life. Need I say more?\n\nDon't expect this game to be fast-paced. It's World War 2 after all

I never played much strategy games except Total War series, (which strategy aspect is not challenging if you will so , I would say casual friendly, one can just sit and enjoy epic battles in TW series) but Company of Heroes proved me that I do need to be a strategist or tactician nor prefer games requiring such thinking. In 2006 i played that one only beacuse it was amazing from technical side. Top tier graphics, audio, physics etc. And to this day CoH, now on Steam(New Steam verion) remains most often played game by me. To think that once i was mainly FPS/RPG genre player, and CoH changed that says much about it's quality.

The game has some flaws. It is not quite as realistic as it could be to create an authentic experience, but the gameplay is super solid and a lot of fun. The DLC doesn't break the game like in CoH2 yet it is worth it's price for a fan for sure... ever since the new steam version came out there have been a lot of problems with matchmaking, connecting to other players, etc. but after multiple fixes and updates it is working rather smoothly now 90% of the time... the only problem is, the amount of people playing is dropping so it might be hard to find someone to play....\n\nStill it remains one of my favorite games of all time ...

This expansion of the superlative Company of Heroes is not vital, but it's a lot of fun. It adds two new factions--the British (defensive fighters extraordinaire) and the Panzer Elite (mobility-based)--and two great new campaigns. It expands the Company of Heroes experience quite a bit by offering more variety in gameplay. It also comes at a spiffy price.\n\nIt's a good buy!
This expansion adds 2 more single player campaigns where one follows the Panzer Elite side and the other follows the British. Worth it if you enjoyed the original game.

Opposing Fronts is the first expansion to Company of Heroes, and is by far the single most important of the pieces to pick up. OF adds the British and the Panzer Elite factions into the game. Britian is my personal favorite faction, and it favors strong, fortified defence and a generalized infantry-centric army that can deal with any threats, athough not reallty specializing in any field. Meanwhile, the Panzer Elite (Poorly named as they have only one actual tank) focuses on an extremely offensive and mobile army in which highly specailized vechicles perform a narrow role, and thus every unit serves a spefific purpose. Both factions are extremly unique, and do not feel like retooled American/Wehrmacht. OF also adds two new campaigns for the two new factions. In all, if you loved CoH, you will adore the hell out of this expansion.\n\nNOTE: Getting this expansion only, without the base or Tales of Valor, means that you will only be able to play as the British or Panzer Elite.

#1 game I have been playing recently, better than the original Coh, and has unlocks. To get full effect of the game, I suggest buying Tales of Valor as well, because it is required to get a couple of unlocks, medals, armies (American and Wehrmacht), and even a different game mode!

CoH is possibly the best RTS I've ever played. It's very fast-paced and forces you to micromanage your units every step of the game. This makes it one of the most immersive games I've ever played in general. I've often found myself talking to myself as if I were actually giving orders in real life. If you've ever been remotely interested in the RTS genre or WWII games, this is a must buy. If you can, buy CoH: Tales of Valor, as I believe it comes with all the factions. Every faction is well balanced with unique strengths & weaknesses, the gameplay is tight & polished, the graphics are beautiful, and the community is still very, very much alive on the new Steam version.

My favorite RTS game of all time for a wide variety of reasons, and in my opinion the only GOOD world war two strategy game on the market. Not micro heavy enough to scare away those unfamiliar with the genre, but still quite deep to provide a more than satisfying experience to those who are willing to give it a try. Opposing fronts adds two new factions, and tales of valor adds more 'hero centric' singleplayer missions and a cadre of entertaining multiplayer modes such as a delightful twist on  the last stand mode. The only downside I can think of for the game is the lack of people to play it with!

An excellent expansion for an excellent game, OF introduces 2 radically different factions to the base game, the British and the Panzaer Elite and 2 new campaigns allowing you to play as the Brisith 2nd army during the liberation of Caen and the Kampfgruppe Lehr during the counter offensive agaisnt the Operation Market Garden

On the online front the tactical gameplay of Company of Heroes ramains intact, that doesnt means everything is the same, the new factions will require veteran players to think in new ways in order to master and counter both new factions, base building becomes expecially important for the british thanks to the unique defenses they have access to, while the Panzer elite player must concentrate his/her efforts on keeping a steady offensive, exploiting the faction's main asset, mobility

sure nowadays the online experience of COH is unfortunately plagued by some noticeable unbalance, but COHOF is still an outstanding RTS well worth your money and time

Deutschland uber alles simulator

The entire Company of Heroes collection is a great RTS, especially for those who traditionally don't like to play this genre of game due to the punishing difficulty on new players (seen in the big name ones, like StarCraft). The fact that this is a World War 2 setting will also draw out some people to try the game out.

CoH doesn't have you building your base and gathering resources, rather it has you capturing points on the maps which provide you with increased resources and army capacity. This lets you worry more about managing position on the battlefield, rather than managing how many drones you have collecting resources. As you play more, you will see little nuances of the game that make the game deeper and more complex, like cover behind walls, flanking, and all the sorts of things you may expect from playing an in-depth, turn-based, strategy game.

Overall, the CoH collection of games have a great single player campaign experience, and a thriving multiplayer community. If you like real-world settings for war, this RTS is probably for you.

Note: Only played CoH's Campaign and my hours are chalked up against the new steam edition of CoH.\n\nOpposing Fronts adds a little extra variety to the units in COH by introducing two new factions; British Army units and a mobile german faction called Kampfgruppe Lehr. This factions add some nice new units and abilities. Additionally, Opposing Fronts also adds two additional campaigns, one for each faction. The missions in these campaigns, along with the camapigns themselves, felt unique and enjoyable, with some nice flavour story and not just rehashings from the first game.

The entire Company of Heroes collection is a great RTS, especially for those who traditionally don't like to play this genre of game due to the punishing difficulty on new players (seen in the big name ones, like StarCraft). The fact that this is a World War 2 setting will also draw out some people to try the game out.

CoH doesn't have you building your base and gathering resources, rather it has you capturing points on the maps which provide you with increased resources and army capacity. This lets you worry more about managing position on the battlefield, rather than managing how many drones you have collecting resources. As you play more, you will see little nuances of the game that make the game deeper and more complex, like cover behind walls, flanking, and all the sorts of things you may expect from playing an in-depth, turn-based, strategy game.

Overall, the CoH collection of games have a great single player campaign experience, and a thriving multiplayer community. If you like real-world settings for war, this RTS is probably for you.
